problem.markdown:
>>1. Which deployment methods are officially recommended by the Open edX project?<< [x] Kubernetes [x] Tutor Local [!] Manual installation [x] Third-party hosting solutions
>>2. Before installing Tutor, what is a prerequisite regarding the server you're using?<< (!) It must be a Windows server. ( ) It should have a SQL database pre-installed. (x) It should have access to the internet and sufficient resources (RAM, compute power, disk space). ( ) It must be hosted on a cloud service like AWS or Google Cloud.
>>3. When deploying Open edX with Tutor to Kubernetes, what is the assumed prerequisite concerning tools?<< (!) Helm installed ( ) node 18 or newer (x) kubectl installed and configured ( ) Docker Desktop installed
>>4. Which of the following is not a step in setting up DNS records for your Open edX instance?<< (!) Create an A record pointing to your server's IP address. (x) Define a TXT record with your LMS’s hostname ( ) Setting up a wildcard CNAME record for subdomains. ( ) Setting up DNS before launching Tutor.
>>5. Why would you choose a Kubernetes deployment over a Tutor Local deployment for Open edX?<< (!) Kubernetes deployment is easier to set up. (x) Kubernetes allows for better scalability and resilience. ( ) Kubernetes is the only way to use Tutor. ( ) Tutor Local does not support custom plugins.
>>6. What is a benefit of using Tutor plugins for deploying Open edX on Kubernetes?<< (!) It allows direct modification of Open edX core code. (x) It enables customization and addition of features without altering the core Tutor application. ( ) Plugins are mandatory for Kubernetes deployments. ( ) Tutor plugins replace the need for kubectl.
>>7. What is the purpose of using Terraform or similar tools in Open edX deployments?<< (!) They replace the need for Tutor in managing Open edX. ( ) They are specifically designed for theme customization of Open edX. (x) They automate and make infrastructure setup reproducible. ( ) They provide a graphical interface for managing Open edX instances.
>>8. In the context of Open edX, what does configuring Django Settings enable?<< (!) Direct modification of k8s deployment scripts. (x) Adjustment of various aspects of the Open edX installation. ( ) Configuration of cloud provider settings only. ( ) Enabling SSL certificates for secure connections.
>>9. How can you deploy custom XBlocks in Open edX using Tutor?<< (!) By adding them to the OPENEDX_EXTRA_PIP_REQUIREMENTS configuration variable. ( ) Uploading the XBlock directly through the LMS admin panel. ( ) Manually copying XBlock code into the edx-platform directory. ( ) Creating a dedicated Tutor plugin for each XBlock.
>>10. What is required when performing upgrades of Open edX instances via Tutor?<< (!) Deleting the old instance and starting over with the new version. ( ) Manual migration of all course content to the new version. (x) Running Tutor commands which automate upgrade procedures. ( ) Upgrading is automatic and doesn't require any action.
>>11. When we say an Open edX release is “supported”, what do we mean?<< [x] The release receives active bug fixes [!] New features and functionality is being added continuously [x] The release receives active security fixes [x] The community will be able to help you with issues encountered in upgrading from the last release to the new supported release >>12. How often should you update your Open edX instance?<< (!) Updates are never needed as Open edX releases are supported indefinitely ( ) Once per year, as Open edX releases are supported for a year (x) Every six months, as Open edX releases are supported for six months ( ) Daily
problem.label: 1. Which deployment methods are officially recommended by the Open edX project? (Select 3)
2. Before installing Tutor, what is a prerequisite regarding the server you're using?

choicegroup.choice: It must be a Windows server.
It should have a SQL database pre-installed.
It should have access to the internet and sufficient resources (RAM, compute power, disk space).
It must be hosted on a cloud service like AWS or Google Cloud.

choicegroup.choice: Helm installed
Node 18 or newer
Kubectl installed and configured

choicegroup.choice: Create an A record pointing to your server's IP address.
Define a TXT record with your LMS’s hostname
Setting up a wildcard CNAME record for subdomains.
Setting up DNS before launching Tutor.

choicegroup.choice: Kubernetes deployment is easier to set up.

Kubernetes is the only way to use Tutor.

choicegroup.choice: It allows direct modification of Open edX core code.

choicegroup.choice: They replace the need for Tutor in managing Open edX.

choicegroup.choice: Direct modification of k8s deployment scripts.

choicegroup.choice: By adding them to the OPENEDX_EXTRA_PIP_REQUIREMENTS configuration variable.
Uploading the XBlock directly through the LMS admin panel.

problem.label: 10. What is required when performing upgrades of Open edX instances via Tutor?

choicegroup.choice: Deleting the old instance and starting over with the new version.
Manual migration of all course content to the new version.
Running Tutor commands which automate upgrade procedures.
Upgrading is automatic and doesn't require any action.

problem.label: 11. When we say an Open edX release is “supported”, what do we mean? (Select 3)

checkboxgroup.choice: The release receives active bug fixes
New features and functionality is being added continuously
The release receives active security fixes
The community will be able to help you with issues encountered in upgrading from the last release to the new supported release

problem.label: 12. How often should you update your Open edX instance?

choicegroup.choice: Updates are never needed as Open edX releases are supported indefinitely
Once per year, as Open edX releases are supported for a year
Every six months, as Open edX releases are supported for six months
Daily
